title: Romney campaign: Ohio is still competitive
content:
VANDALIA , Ohio — Mitt Romney ’ s campaign insists it ’ s not worried about a spate of public polls showing the campaign behind by as many as 8 points in Ohio , making more difficult the GOP nominee ’ s path to victory in the electoral college .
“ There ’ s just a nice wide open path , and so I ’ m not — we ’ re not in a situation where we ’ re forced into this boxed canyon to say , ‘ We have to win this string of states , ’ ” Romney political director Rich Beeson said in a briefing with reporters aboard Romney ’ s campaign plane while headed to a rally here .
But without Ohio and its 18 electoral college votes , Romney ’ s path to the 270 votes needed to secure the White House gets a lot tighter . No Republican has lost Ohio and won the White House .
“ If we lose Ohio , can we still win ? ” Beeson said , repeating the question asked of him by reporters . “ I say if it ’ s and buts were candy and nuts , everyday would be Christmas . … I just don ’ t deal in if-then statements . ”
Beeson compared states on the map to children ( he has two boys , ) saying individual states can ’ t be written off .
“ It ’ s like kids out there — you ’ re not ever going to say , ‘ I ’ m going to lose one of my kids , ’ ” Beeson said . He added , “ So we don ’ t sit down , I don ’ t sit down and sort of lop those off . I prefer to look at the map holistically . ”
Public polling shows President Barack Obama gaining ground in Ohio , including a Washington Post poll released Tuesday that found Romney trailing by 8 percentage points .
Beeson pointed to other states where he thinks Romney will be competitive , like Wisconsin , as proof that the GOP nominee ’ s route to 270 isn ’ t limited to Ohio .
“ The president had to go into Wisconsin , for the first time in — first time in that state since 1984 , ” Beeson said . “ When you talk about Republicans in a tie race in Wisconsin and we haven ’ t won since 1984 — this is a wide open map . ”
But even with Wisconsin ’ s 10 electoral votes , Romney is going to have to pick up a state where he currently trails in the polls , like Virginia or Florida .
It ’ s clear that Ohio is a high priority for Romney .
Romney ’ s campaign launched an Ohio bus tour on Monday . Paul Ryan headlined the first day-and-a half , holding rallies in the southwestern part of the state . Romney joined him here for a rally on Tuesday afternoon . The GOP nominee will finish the tour Wednesday , traveling from Columbus to Cleveland with stops along the way .
At Romney ’ s first stop here , he raised Democratic eyebrows when he said Obama hadn ’ t raised taxes in his first term in office .
“ I admit this , he has one thing he did not do in his first four years , said he ’ s going to do in his next four years , which is to raise taxes , ” Romney said at an airport campaign rally . The GOP nominee has repeatedly accused Obama of raising taxes , most frequently pointing to the Obama health care plan as a tax increase on the middle class .
content_original:
Mitt camp: Ohio still competitive

VANDALIA, Ohio — Mitt Romney’s campaign insists it’s not worried about a spate of public polls showing the campaign behind by as many as 8 points in Ohio, making more difficult the GOP nominee’s path to victory in the electoral college.

“There’s just a nice wide open path, and so I’m not — we’re not in a situation where we’re forced into this boxed canyon to say, ‘We have to win this string of states,’” Romney political director Rich Beeson said in a briefing with reporters aboard Romney’s campaign plane while headed to a rally here.

Story Continued Below

( See also: POLITICO's swing-state map)

But without Ohio and its 18 electoral college votes, Romney’s path to the 270 votes needed to secure the White House gets a lot tighter. No Republican has lost Ohio and won the White House.

“If we lose Ohio, can we still win?” Beeson said, repeating the question asked of him by reporters. “I say if it’s and buts were candy and nuts, everyday would be Christmas. … I just don’t deal in if-then statements.”

Beeson compared states on the map to children (he has two boys,) saying individual states can’t be written off.

“It’s like kids out there — you’re not ever going to say, ‘I’m going to lose one of my kids,’” Beeson said. He added, “So we don’t sit down, I don’t sit down and sort of lop those off. I prefer to look at the map holistically.”

Public polling shows President Barack Obama gaining ground in Ohio, including a Washington Post poll released Tuesday that found Romney trailing by 8 percentage points.

Beeson pointed to other states where he thinks Romney will be competitive, like Wisconsin, as proof that the GOP nominee’s route to 270 isn’t limited to Ohio.

“The president had to go into Wisconsin, for the first time in — first time in that state since 1984,” Beeson said. “When you talk about Republicans in a tie race in Wisconsin and we haven’t won since 1984 — this is a wide open map.”

But even with Wisconsin’s 10 electoral votes, Romney is going to have to pick up a state where he currently trails in the polls, like Virginia or Florida.

It’s clear that Ohio is a high priority for Romney.

Romney’s campaign launched an Ohio bus tour on Monday. Paul Ryan headlined the first day-and-a half, holding rallies in the southwestern part of the state. Romney joined him here for a rally on Tuesday afternoon. The GOP nominee will finish the tour Wednesday, traveling from Columbus to Cleveland with stops along the way.

( See also: POLITICO's 2012 poll tracker)

At Romney’s first stop here, he raised Democratic eyebrows when he said Obama hadn’t raised taxes in his first term in office.

“I admit this, he has one thing he did not do in his first four years, said he’s going to do in his next four years, which is to raise taxes,” Romney said at an airport campaign rally. The GOP nominee has repeatedly accused Obama of raising taxes, most frequently pointing to the Obama health care plan as a tax increase on the middle class.
